w:r.w:t: División de Diseño, Ingeniería y Arquitectura
Departamento de Tecnologías de la Información y Computación

j. An ability to apply mathematical foundations, algorithmic principles, and computer science theory in the modeling and design of computer-based systems in a way that demonstrates comprehension of the tradeoffs involved in design choices.
Data of the group and the teacher

The students have advanced knowledge of program development, debugging and implementation in C language, to design and develop solutions that use computational resources efficiently. The students have full understanding of the process administration in an Operating System, and the techniques for synchronization and communication between them. The students know the advantages of concurrent algorithms and multithreaded programs, and implement them with tools that ensure efficiency.
General policies for the development of the course:
Students must comply with at least an 80% attendance to the class sessions
The standard discipline rules will be upheld.
Students that are doing other activities not related to the subject during classes will be asked to leave the classroom
The main type of assignments during the semester will be programming exercises. Additionally, there will be some written exercises
All assignments must be submitted via Blackboard before the specified deadline. Late submissions will not be accepted.
All exercises and programs submitted MUST have your name on them. In the case of programs your name should appear as a comment at the very top of the file. 10 points will be deducted otherwise.
Programs that are found to be too similar to those of a classmate will receive a grade of 0, for both students involved.
You must test your programs before submitting them. If there are errors that you could have solved by simply running the program, you will get a deduction of 30 points
All code must be written in English. 10 points will be deducted otherwise.
If you need additional help with the material seen in class, we can meet at the Sala de Profesores, on the following times:
Review of C programming and syntax
Topic 2. Introduction to the UNIX operating system
Handling priorities and relationships between processes (pipes, FIFO)
Practice exercises for the partial evaluation
Basic concepts of signals and the corresponding functions
Interrupting the execution of system calls
Concepts of parallel and concurrent programming
Identification, creation, synchronization and termination of threads
System support for synchronization operations (mutual exclusion, semaphores, conditions, etc.)
Practice exercises for the partial evaluation
Measurement and analysis of computing performance (cache hit)
Algorithmic design based on threads and patterns
Resources for concurrent programming (OpenMP and WinThreads)
Introduction to programming multicore architectures of distributed computing (MPI)
Teaching-learning (brief description of how the course will be developed):

The teaching methodology to be followed consists of a combination of various strategies and instructional techniques (exhibition, experiential, vestibular, self-administered and group discussion) that aim to ensure that students integrate the acquired knowledge and use their analytical skills and creative, the preparation of research reports, among others.
The theoretical concepts will be presented by the teacher and students will conduct individual and collaborative activities to enhance knowledge practices related to the topics discussed in class.
Students also study conducted individual activities of some issues and later in group activities face the doubts that have arisen during the self-study will be resolved.
Learning activities and other teaching techniques are:
W. Richard Stevens and Stephen A. Rago (2013). Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment. Addison-Wesley Professional; 3 Edition. ISBN 978-0321637734
Robert Cook (2011). An Introduction to Parallel Programming with OpenMP, MPI and PThreads. Cook's Books; 1.0 edition.
Hoover Adam (2010). System programming with C and Unix. Addison-Wesley. 1 edition. ISBN 978-0136067122
Brian W. Kernighan, Dennis M. Ritchie. The C Programming Language (2nd Edition), Prentice Hall PTR, ISBN 978-0131103627
Brian W. Kernighan, Rob Pike. The Practice of Programming, Addison-Wesley Professional, ISBN 978-0201615869
Andy Oram, Greg Wilson. Beautiful Code: Leading Programmers Explain How They Think, O'Reilly
